slides.ocrText: Workers’ Compensation Exposures

Lesson
objectives

¢ Explain the purposes of Workers’
Compensation Medical Details exposures

« Use ICD-10 codes on a Med Pay exposure

¢ Describe the Medical Case Management
process

* Define MMI

Tanvi
Adjuster We

In adjudicating a Workers’
Compensation claim, what special
exposure types are involved? And how
do | work with them?

slides.originalNotes:
Line of business model: Overview
ClaimCenter is delivered out of the box with several pre- configured business lines in the LOB model. You can see these when adding a new claim or exposure- Based on the line of business presented or selected, you will have different options.

The structure of the Line of Business is defined in six distinct typelists:

LossType is a broad industry category for P&C insurance activity. A claim's Loss Type helps determine the IJI elements to use or display. For example, the New Claim Wizard has a Loss Details screen. Details about the injured worker's employment data and injuries appear in the IJI only when the LossType is Worker's Comp.  The LOB (line of business)  level splits the LossType into more granular levels for reporting purposes- This level is used for reporting and management by a carrier and can roughly be seen as business units. A given LossType may have many Lines of Business associated with it. 

Policy Type defines the types of policies the insurer sells- A policy is a product that is sold to customers and that promises to pay money when a specified LossType occurs. In the base configuration, the only Policy Type under the Workers' Comp LOB is the Workers' Comp policy, but one LOB may have many Policy Types..

A Coverage Type (CovType) defines specific items that the carrier will indemnify as part of the policy contract- A Policy Type can include many CoverageTypes-

Exposure Typeis a set of information needed for a given exposure during claims processing. It relates to one or more CoverageTypes.

Coverage Sub type is a pairing of one ExposureType and one CoverageType, used to implement the many-to- many relationship between CoverageTypes and ExposureTypes
slides.notes:

slides.originalNotes:
Workers' compensation exposure types
Recall that an exposure is a set of data used to track a potential payment from one coverage to one claimant.

(In the case of Workers’ Compensation, the coverage(s) is (are) determined by applicable laws/acts/regulations.)

Note that you do not manually create exposures on a Workers’ Compensation claim. They are automatically created when certain conditions are met.
slides.notes:
Workers' compensation exposure types
Recall that an exposure is a set of data used to track a potential payment from one coverage to one claimant.

(In the case of Workers’ Compensation, the coverage(s) is (are) determined by applicable laws/acts/regulations.)

Note that you do not manually create exposures on a Workers’ Compensation claim. They are automatically created when certain conditions are met.
slides.ocrText:
| Workers’ compensation exposure types G

¢ Workers’ compensation coverage generally covers two large
categories of losses:

* Medical costs associated with work-related injuries or illnesses (“Med Pay”)

+ Wage replacement for time lost from work due to work-related injuries or illnesses
(“Indemnity”)

¢ While many workers’ compensation claims are MO (Medical Only), wo
indemnity is an important part of some WC claims

+ There are many complex calculations, laws, factors, and details involved in paying F

indemnity benefits

+ Each jurisdiction may pay differently, depending on many factors (rate of pay, ability
to work, totally/partially disabled, etc.)

slides.originalNotes:
Administration: Searching and managing ICD-IO Codes
Entering the first few characters (case-sensitive) of a code will retrieve all codes that "start with“ that fragment. You may also navigate through ICD-IO codes by clicking on an entered code on an existing claim. The code contains a link to www.icdlOdata.com which will provide information about the code (full name, description and documentation) from the site as well as navigation to other sibling codes in the hierarchy.

A user with appropriate permissions may manage ICD-IO codes in the Administration tab. Here you may add codes, designate codes as chronic, and set available and expiration dates for codes. The Administration tab is also where ICD-IO codes may also be added by using the Import Data utility (Administration tab Utilities Import Data) or a command-line tool.

slides.originalNotes:
Medical Case Management card
While medical case management (MCM, or MedCase) is usually used for severe, "catastrophic", or complex injuries or medical issues, it could be used at any time. Each insurer may decide what determines the necessity for medical case management. An insurer may decide to pursue MCM on any claims with lost time of 1 week or more. An insurer may decide to pursue MCM on any claim involving back injuries or surgery (inpatient or outpatient) or hospitalization.

A "catastrophic" WC claim is a claim involving an IW that has severe, debilitating, or long-term injuries or illnesses. Back/spinal injuries, paralysis, brain damage,  and amputation are examples of catastrophic claims. Generally, any catastrophic claim will require medical case management.

The purpose of the Medical Case Mgmt (Management) card is to provide a summary of information from Loss Details. It can represent multiple injuries to a single Injured Worker (IW). This is what the nurse case manager works on. The screenshot shows a newly created Medical Case Mgmt card, where sparse information has been gathered.  This is likely what a case manager will see when they first begin work. As case management work proceeds, each list view may have multiple pieces of data and information.

slides.originalNotes:
Medical Case Management
Medical Case Management (MCM) also helps insurers control costs by ensuring only the necessary treatments are being pursued.

Depending on state or provincial laws as well as other nationalregulations (if applicable), important limits and conditions may be imposed on medical treatments and medical costs associated with injured workers.

States and insurance boards are increasingly scrutinizing this process by setting maximums,  limits and regulations (that is, you can't have more than 24 chiropractic visits).

Because of the high costs associated with medical treatments in general, workers’ compensation is often a political issue. Many states, state insurance boards, and other governmental bodies try to lower costs by imposing fee schedules, treatment limits, safety training and certification programs, to try to lower workers' compensation costs. Much of what happens regarding workers' compensation rights and law occurs at the state or provincial level. Each state may have very different laws and regulations and practices (for example, many states do not follow NCCI standards or NCCI class codes).

In Europe and other parts of the world, workers' compensation regulations are frequently determined at the national level.
slides.notes:
Medical Case Management
Medical Case Management (MCM) also helps insurers control costs by ensuring only the necessary treatments are being pursued.

Depending on state or provincial laws as well as other nationalregulations (if applicable), important limits and conditions may be imposed on medical treatments and medical costs associated with injured workers.

States and insurance boards are increasingly scrutinizing this process by setting maximums,  limits and regulations (that is, you can't have more than 24 chiropractic visits).

Because of the high costs associated with medical treatments in general, workers’ compensation is often a political issue. Many states, state insurance boards, and other governmental bodies try to lower costs by imposing fee schedules, treatment limits, safety training and certification programs, to try to lower workers' compensation costs. Much of what happens regarding workers' compensation rights and law occurs at the state or provincial level. Each state may have very different laws and regulations and practices (for example, many states do not follow NCCI standards or NCCI class codes).

In Europe and other parts of the world, workers' compensation regulations are frequently determined at the national level.
slides.ocrText:
| Medical Case Management G&G

* The primary purpose of Medical Case Management (MCM, or MedCase) is:
+ Achievement of MMI (Maximum Medical Improvement)* for a compensable injury
+ Facilitating RTW (Return to Work)

* In other words, treat with the goal of getting the IW back on the job as soon as is safe and medically
possible
+ Each insurer determines its own criteria for pursuing MCM

* The nurse case manager or adjuster reviews diagnoses and medical treatment plans to ensure that
the treatment matches the diagnosis
+ Only appropriate treatments are covered

* In addition, it gives options and choices to the Primary Treating Physician (PTP) so they do what is
covered as much as possible

*Note: California uses the term P&S (Permanent and Stationary) instead of MMI, and Ontario uses the term MMR (Maximum
Medical Recovery).

| Nurse case manager

¢ Insurers often employ nurse case managers to handle WC claims’ MCM
responsibilities
* These may be employees of the insurer or third-party vendor contractors
« The nurse case manager works with the adjuster to ensure that the treatment(s)
goes as planned, and is in line with the diagnosis(es)

* The nurse case manager also works with medical providers such as physical
therapists, massage therapists, chiropractors, and so on, to monitor treatments

Gi

| Example case management scenario G

« IW experiences severe back pain
¢ Treatment guidelines say MRI only after X number of PT sessions

« It may be prudent not to follow the treatment guidelines, at the
discretion of the adjuster and nurse case manager
* A good nurse case manager may suspect a more severe back injury and
demand an MRI right away

« Running the MRI may reveal more serious back issues for which physical
therapy may be ineffective or even harmful, altering the proposed treatment

Se te >

Indemnity exposure

click here

| Indemnity (time loss) exposure creation G

¢ Usually created during intake by answering “yes” to “Lost Time from e
Work?” in the New Claim Wizard
+ May also be created by answering “Yes” to “Injury/Illness Result in Death?” (regardless
of answer to “Lost Time from Work?”)
* Can also be created after claim creation by answering “Yes” to “Lost Time from
Work” in Loss Details
* Example: A worker is injured at the end of the day and taken to the hospital

+ A First Report of Injury (FROI) claim is entered at this time, but it is not known whether the worker will
lose time from work

+ A few days later, the adjuster learns that the worker has missed work due to a longer-than-expected
hospitalization

+ The adjuster indicates that there is “Lost Time from Work’ in the Loss Details screen, and the Time
Loss exposure is created

Indemnity benefit parameters
Administering and editing these parameters is covered in the EWorkers' Comp: AdministeringClaimCenter" lesson of the ClaimCenter Intro Essentials  (Workers' Compensation) course.  In ClaimCenter 8.x, the benefit parameters are considered •past“ benefit parameters because they may only have information for calendar year 2008. Consult governmental WC boards or state agencies for the last benefit parameter rates.

Indemnity benefit parameters
Administering and editing these parameters is covered in the EWorkers' Comp: AdministeringClaimCenter" lesson of the ClaimCenter Intro Essentials  (Workers' Compensation) course.  In ClaimCenter 8.x, the benefit parameters are considered •past“ benefit parameters because they may only have information for calendar year 2008. slides.ocrText:
| Indemnity benefit parameters

Benefits are determined by
+ Setup steps
+ Gathering IW details (such as pay stubs)
ClaimCenter sample data includes some sample past benefit parameters for
certain jurisdictions
For example, in the first half of 2017, the State of Illinois (IL):

+ Pays 67% of wages
+ Maximum weekly benefit of $1,076.38
+ Minimum weekly benefit of $538.19
+ Has a waiting period of three days

These benefit parameters can be edited and administered

+ Must be made valid for the time period to be used on Time Loss claims

slides.originalNotes:
WC disability types
Reminder: MMI = Maximum Medical Improvement.

The definition of each classification is provided later in this lesson.

At a high level, the difference between temporary disability and permanent disability is that temporary disability is pre-MMI and permanent disability is  MMI. Permanent disability means either the worker permanently cannot work at all or can only work in a limited fashion.
slides.notes:
WC disability types
Reminder: MMI = Maximum Medical Improvement.

The definition of each classification is provided later in this lesson.

At a high level, the difference between temporary disability and permanent disability is that temporary disability is pre-MMI and permanent disability is  MMI. Permanent disability means either the worker permanently cannot work at all or can only work in a limited fashion.
slides.ocrText:
| WC disability types G

¢ There are four classifications in workers’ compensation insurance for benefit types:
1. TTD (Temporary Total Disability)
2. TPD (Temporary Partial Disability)
3. PPD (Permanent Partial Disability)
4. PTD (Permanent Total Disability)

¢ Insurers and jurisdictions may, at times, distinguish only between “Temporary” and
“Permanent,” or TD and PD, and set reserves accordingly

« The major difference between temporary and permanent is MMI

¢ These benefit types always appear on the “Benefits” card of a Workers’

Compensation Time Loss exposure
Of
a) &

|

“&S

slides.originalNotes:
Complexity of benefit payments
Some jurisdictions will pay immediately if the worker is hospitalized or a victim of crime and waive the waiting period.  Some jurisdictions adjust comp rates based on number of IW’s dependents. Some jurisdiction  (i.e. Florida, Pennsylvania) have their own more complex comp rate formulas (instead of the standard 67% of AWW), or disregard TPD altogether (i.e New Jersey).

Some workers come back to work but fall ill again and go off work.

Often the adjuster cannot make an exact calculation at a point in time because it is not known yet if the worker is back at work yet, ready to work, or able to work 
alternate job. Many (if not all) of the factors and complexities of payroll processing apply to WC benefit payments.
slides.notes:
Complexity of benefit payments
Some jurisdictions will pay immediately if the worker is hospitalized or a victim of crime and waive the waiting period.  Some jurisdictions adjust comp rates based on number of IW’s dependents. Some jurisdiction  (i.e. Florida, Pennsylvania) have their own more complex comp rate formulas (instead of the standard 67% of AWW), or disregard TPD altogether (i.e New Jersey).

Some workers come back to work but fall ill again and go off work.

Often the adjuster cannot make an exact calculation at a point in time because it is not known yet if the worker is back at work yet, ready to work, or able to work 
alternate job. Many (if not all) of the factors and complexities of payroll processing apply to WC benefit payments.
slides.ocrText:
| Complexity of benefit payments

¢ This lesson presents examples and scenarios as a starting point to
see how ClaimCenter can handle indemnity payments

claims

¢ The staring point is usually paying a percentage (for example, 67%) of the
worker’s ordinary paycheck, but...
+ Is there a waiting period?
+ Was the worker hospitalized, or the victim of crime?
+ Did the worker come back on modified duty, or part-time? If so, for how long?
+ Are there expected bonuses or seasonal employment?
+ How to factor in child support, alimony, and similar payments
+ How do state/governmental regulations affect the calculation? ( @
+ Andsoon @

Gi

¢ Inreality, benefit calculations can be the most complex aspect of Workers’ Comp

| Average Weekly Wage

+ Adjusters may enter an approximate AWW or the
weekly wage information of the latest pay stub
during intake or at the start of adjudication

+ Later, the AWW will be more accurately calculated
as up to (sometimes) the last 52 weeks of salary
history are obtained

¢« The AWW can be entered in the New Claim Wizard or on Loss Details

+ Itis then carried over to the Time Loss exposure Benefits card as “Weekly Wage (Pre-Injury)”

« AWW can be edited at any time, even after payments are made

slides.originalNotes:
TTD process
Recall that in TTD the worker is off work completely.

Differential example: an IW with an AWW of $800 and Post-Injury wage of $500 has a Differential of $300
slides.notes:
TTD process
Recall that in TTD the worker is off work completely.

Differential example: an IW with an AWW of $800 and Post-Injury wage of $500 has a Differential of $300
slides.ocrText:
TTD process G

Scenario: |W has just been injured and cannot work, but is expected to recover

1.

Get the AWW and the Post-Injury weekly wage amount “Differential”
Differential = AWW -— Post-Injury weekly wage

If Differential is above the maximum state comp rate, pay out the maximum state comp rate
If Differential is below the minimum state comp rate, pay out the minimum state comp rate
If comp rate is not calculated by the above,

+ Calculate AWW * 67%

Determine duration

+ Benefit period usually begins on date of injury

+ Apply waiting period if warranted

TPD process G

Scenario: IW has just been injured, but can work in a limited fashion for a
temporary period of time

1.

ak on

Get the AWW and the Post-Injury weekly wage amount “Differential”
Differential = AWW -— Post-Injury weekly wage

If Differential is above the maximum state comp rate, pay out the maximum state comp rate
If Differential is below the minimum state comp rate, pay out the minimum state comp rate
If neither is true, calculate AWW * 67%

Determine duration

+ Benefit period usually begins on date of injury

+ Apply waiting period if warranted

slides.originalNotes:
Permanent Partial and Total Disa bility
The MMI (Maximum Medical  Improvement) threshold is the point at which the IW has been treated to a point of healing completely, or to an exhaustion of treatment options and/or limits.  An example would be a worker that due to a severe fall, lost useof their leg. Through therapy, P T, treatment and rest, the worker can regain some use of their leg  (70%) after many months, but no additional use is available or medically possible. The worker is now on permanent disability.

Some jurisdictions provide specific PPD benefits, known as Supplemental Job Displacement Benefits". This is money towards retraining, skill/vocational training in the form of a lump sum voucher (books, tools, licensing exam fees and general licensingfees) (usually in the range of $5,000 to $8,000).

Settlements can be reached in regard to PD payments between the carrier and the claimant.

Due to the severity and/or long- term effects of Permanent Disability claims, these kinds of claims are often classified as •Catastrophic" claims.
slides.notes:
Permanent Partial and Total Disa bility
The MMI (Maximum Medical  Improvement) threshold is the point at which the IW has been treated to a point of healing completely, or to an exhaustion of treatment options and/or limits.  An example would be a worker that due to a severe fall, lost useof their leg. Through therapy, P T, treatment and rest, the worker can regain some use of their leg  (70%) after many months, but no additional use is available or medically possible. The worker is now on permanent disability.

Some jurisdictions provide specific PPD benefits, known as Supplemental Job Displacement Benefits". This is money towards retraining, skill/vocational training in the form of a lump sum voucher (books, tools, licensing exam fees and general licensingfees) (usually in the range of $5,000 to $8,000).

Settlements can be reached in regard to PD payments between the carrier and the claimant.

Due to the severity and/or long- term effects of Permanent Disability claims, these kinds of claims are often classified as •Catastrophic" claims.
slides.ocrText:
| Permanent Partial and Total Disability G&G

* Permanent disability is generally defined as payments when your injury causes a
permanent disability or impairment beyond the MMI threshold (i.e., no further
healing is expected)

+ Permanent partial disability (PPD) example: /W has lost an eye, but can still work in a limited fashion
after MMI has been achieved

+ Permanent Total Disability (PTD) example: /W is paralyzed and permanently unable to work at all

¢« Both PPD and PTD are after MMI has been achieved

+ These benefits may sometimes be paid as a lump-sum settlement rather than a series of checks over
a payment period

| PPD terms and conditions Gi

PPD is often divided by body part (for example, the IW literally loses an arm anda
leg) but paid concurrently

Due to the permanency of the work displacement, the potential for “lifetime”
payments are capped using limits and restrictions

* Often governed by jurisdiction

+ Example: A 42% impairment rating means 300 weeks maximum PPD payments

Sample date provides a set of sample limits for the state of California

The Administrator may alter or augment these limits in the Administration screen

| PPD (Permanent Partial Disability) rating G

PPD is subject to jurisdictional limits including:
+ Number of weeks

+ Maximum benefit amount

The PPD rating quantifies the IW’s permanent disability and sets the maximum
number of weeks the IW is paid

PPD is also known as Impairment Rating

Because the worker has limited capacity to work, the purpose is to compensate for
that limited capacity

Example
+ The doctor has determined that IW has lost some ability to move their right arm
+ The PPD rating is 20%

slides.originalNotes:
PPD example
In the example, the comp rate is capped at a total payment of $23,000 (which is $230 x 100). The $230 max state comp rate is used because the impairment rating falls in the first threshold of 1 to 69%. If the impairment rating was, say, 72%, the max comp rate would be $270 (as seen on slide 26).
slides.notes:
PPD example
In the example, the comp rate is capped at a total payment of $23,000 (which is $230 x 100). The $230 max state comp rate is used because the impairment rating falls in the first threshold of 1 to 69%. If the impairment rating was, say, 72%, the max comp rate would be $270 (as seen on slide 26).

slides.notes:
Minimum adjustments
For TPD, if a post-injury weekly wage is available, the "AWW“ would be the differential.
slides.ocrText:
| Minimum adjustments

¢ In general:

« Any time the AWW is greater than the maximum
weekly benefit (for any benefit type), the maximum
weekly benefit amount is used

« Any time the AWW is lesser than the maximum
but greater than the minimum (for any benefit
type), multiply by two-thirds (% of wages)

¢ If the AWW is lesser than the minimum
weekly benefit, then:

* If minimum adjusted by weekly wage ==Yes, use
AWW

¢ If minimum adjusted by weekly wage == No, use
minimum weekly benefit

_——_—

MAX

i

slides.originalNotes:
Minimum adjustment example: TTD
If the minimum adjustment is triggered (as shown above), an explanation text is provided on the Time Loss exposure Benefits card for the "Minimum Adjustment" explaining the lower weekly comp rate.

If Minimum adjusted by Weekly Wage = "No", then the weekly comp rate is set to the min state comp rate and no adjustment text is provided.

| Student exercise

Medical details exposure

| Student exercise

Indemnity exposure

Lesson
objectives ¢ Explain the purposes of Workers’

review Compensation Medical Details exposures
« Use ICD-10 codes on a Med Pay exposure
¢ Describe the Medical Case Management
process
* Define MMI

Question G

,— — What is an ICD-10 code used for on a Workers’ Compensation claim?

4
¢
4

-S S SS  SS SS SSS HS SH

Answer G

,— — What is an ICD-10 code used for on a Workers’ Compensation claim?
¢

¢
7

An ICD-10 code is used to officially identify the medical diagnosis and path of
treatment for an injury or illness. ICD-10 codes are a standard medical classification
system used throughout the world.

- Se SSS e S ee sS e H

Question G

,— — Why would a WC claim need Medical Case Management?

4
¢
4

-S S SS  SS SS SSS HS SH

Answer G

a Why would a WC claim need Medical Case Management?

¢
7

If the injury or illness is severe, long-term or complicated, or if there are many
decisions to be made about differing treatments that may or may not be covered

- Se SSS e S ee sS e H

Question G

_— — Yim is a welder that is injured and hospitalized for a month. The following
oo two months, he works a desk job while recuperating. What benefit types
¢ could Jim be paid?

-S S SS  SS SS SSS HS SH

Answer G

_— — Yim is a welder that is injured and hospitalized for a month. The following
Fa two months, he works a desk job while recuperating. What benefit types
¢ could Jim be paid?

Jim would first be paid TTD (Temporary Total Disability) and then paid TPD
(Temporary Partial Disability)

- Se SSS e S ee sS e H

Question G

_— — Rachel is a security officer who is injured and suffers back pain for
oo several months; but is able to work part time. Her treatment plateaus, and
¢ she still works in a limited capacity after treatment ends (MMI is reached).
What benefit types could Rachel be paid?

-S S SS  SS SS SSS HS SH

Answer G

_— — Rachel is a security officer who is injured and suffers back pain for
Fa several months; but is able to work part time. Her treatment plateaus, and
¢ she still works in a limited capacity after treatment ends (MMI is reached).
What benefit types could Rachel be paid?

Rachel would first be paid TPD (Temporary Partial Disability) because she can still
work, but then could be paid PPD (Permanent Partial Disability) because her disability
persists after MMI.

- Se SSS e S ee sS e H

Question G

,— — What is the Differential, and whatis it used for?

4
¢
4

-S S SS  SS SS SSS HS SH

Answer G

,— — What is the Differential, and whats it used for?
4

¢
7

The Differential (the AWW minus the Post-injury wage) is used to calculate TPD
(Temporary Partial Disability). The Differential itself is usually multiplied by 2/3 to arrive
at the maximum weekly TPD benefit.

- Se SSS e S ee sS e H
